item.title: ~~help with a little problem i cant do it~~
item.dc:creator: @alancarr123 alancarr123
item.description:
@alancarr123 wrote:

Well the CLASSPATH variable is probably correct.
Now just the path variable -.-.
ok… try going to start and searching for JDK or something then some folders should come up right click and open file location.
now click and the top where it says your location
something like computer>documents (JUST FOR EXAMPLE)
when you click it it should turn into computer\documents or something
so then you should have your jdk location, just make sure you have your \bin at the end because thats the file it’s in.

Read full topic

item.title: ~~help with a little problem i cant do it~~
item.dc:creator: @alancarr123 alancarr123
item.description:
@alancarr123 wrote:

Ahh great you have same JDK version as me :).
Well here’s what they should be
PATH - %SystemRoot%\system32;%SystemRoot%;%SystemRoot%\Sy stem32\Wbem;C:\Program Files\QuickTime\QTSystem;C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_11\bin
CLASSPATH - C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_11\bin;%CLASSPATH%;
Try them and if they’re wrong, try going through and finding your jdk location.
Gl with your server
BTW Send me a message of what it is and i’ll have a little try of it

Read full topic

item.description:

it says under classpath- CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_11\bin;%CLASSPATH%;

                              PATH= C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_11\bin;

item.source: ~~help with a little problem i cant do it~~

item.title: ~~help with a little problem i cant do it~~
item.dc:creator: @alancarr123 alancarr123
item.description:
@alancarr123 wrote:

It’s Your enviromental variables.
access your enviromental variables by going to start, right clicking computer, click properties.
then go to change settings, go to advanced tab, click enviromental variables.
tell me what version of jdk you got and ill give you your variables
BTW it’s the PATH and CLASSPATH variable that’s wrong.

Read full topic
